channel.title: Your Rights Online - Freedom of Speech?
channel.description:
I have a quote here from someone that tried to argue that they couldn't be infracted because they have 'freedom of speech', and doing so would be unconstitutional. For the safety of that user (because its one of the most uneducated arguments I've seen in a while), I will exclude their name from the quote.
Any action taken against my signature would be unconstitutional. Moparscape.org is hosted within the US. Which means the US Law and Constitution apply to this website. The US Constitution does not apply to the Internet, it applies to the Internet within the US. You're a US Citizen, I am a US Citizen, the forum Owner is a US Citizen. All US Laws apply to us and this forum. If someone in Britain broke a law that exists here, but not in Britain. The US could have that British citizen shipped oversea to stand trial for his actions. I know you're smart to realize that the information I am providing you with is valid and stands. So infract me. Would just make you look bad, not me for excersising my rights. Infracting me for my beliefs is illegal. [snip information that may lead to identification of user] With that said, it would be AGAINST THE LAW to make an infraction like that.
(I will note that the infraction wasn't actually about any beliefs, it was for flame) Now, I will link this: http://blaisegv.com/community-management/does-free-speech-apply-to-online-communities/ So because this is in the debates section, here's the debate: [i]Do you think freedom of speech should apply to all private contexts as well? Should you be able to walk into a store and say whatever you want, even if the store deems it inappropriate? For example, in a toy store, should they be able to kick you out if you start to use a lot of profanity in front of children? Remember, in terms of punishment, it's only in relation to their premises. As in, they can't do anything to you besides kick you out from their store (or ban you from the premises). If you start being extremely offensive to people at school, should it be against the law for them to kick you out?[/i]

item.title: Your Rights Online - Freedom of Speech?
item.dc:creator: @JavaTC JavaTC
item.description:
@JavaTC wrote:

Long story short; if you’re providing a service to the public or have been left in charge of a service then you have every right to prohibit what people can say/do with your service.

Read full topic

Go on twitter, facebook, etc and state a plan to kill obama, where is your freedom of speech then o.o

item.title: Your Rights Online - Freedom of Speech?
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

No. Private businesses can tell you what you can wear/can’t wear and what you can/can’t say outloud.

1st amendment applies to media. It doesn’t mean you can cuss out cops and not be arrested. Verbal assault/harrassment still exists.

Moparisthebest is providing a service. You have to abide by his rules if you wan’t to continue using the service.

Read full topic

Yes, they have every right to throw you out.

item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

British law is good, buut that whole extradition thing is really really silly.
I have no idea why Britain likes to buttkiss America so much, we wouldn’t even be in a recession if we never invested so much into American banks, bad debts and houses (I think, not 100% sure).

item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Bowser jr:

Thank you for confirming my view on British law. I’m glad that Norwegian law forbids the government to extradit me no matter what.

I’m not actually that confident in british law to prevent me being extradited to the us for a crime that isn’t illegal in the uk but at least we aren’t the worse country for extradition laws

item.title: Your Rights Online - Freedom of Speech?
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:24, topic:470888”]dear davidi2, for my christmas present can you release the name of the person who pmed you to be publically shamed for being an absolute moron? thanks

to all those wondering, the first amendment of the united states constitution applies to CONGRESS AND CONGRESS ALONE, go read it if you do not believe me, I’ll quote it for you

Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances.

the first amendment of the united states constitution does not apply to private entities such as these forums, it applies to congress making laws against freedom of speech

and just for the record, freedom of speech doesn’t exist, if you don’t believe me then go teach a class on how to make bombs and methamphetamine and see how far that gets you

EDIT; and just for the record,

If someone in Britain broke a law that exists here, but not in Britain. The US could have that British citizen shipped oversea to stand trial for his actions.

[size=36pt]HAHAHAHAHAH YOU ARE A GOD DAMNED loveING MORON[/size][/quote]Actually, the quoted is true. Take the whole torrent shananagins for example. US is trying to charge the wiki leaks guy, but Ecuador granted him asylum. If he hadn’t hid in the Ecuadorian embassy, US and Sweden would of already processes his charges onto him.

Read full topic

item.title: Your Rights Online - Freedom of Speech?
item.dc:creator: @Owned_Pl0xs Owned_Pl0xs
item.description:
@Owned_Pl0xs wrote:

Even if the US constitution did apply to this forum, the first amendment has exceptions which state:

For example, the Court has decided that the First Amendment provides no protection to obscenity, child pornography, or speech that constitutes “advocacy of the use of force or of law violation ... where such advocacy is directed to inciting or producing imminent lawless action and is likely to incite or produce such action.”

To explain the latter of that statement, things that are unlawful such as slander and libel which the user did partake in would not be protected by the first amendment.

Read full topic
item.source: Your Rights Online - Freedom of Speech?

item.title: Your Rights Online - Freedom of Speech?
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

Some Mopar staff infract on people they disagree with on a personal level; get used to it >.>. @ Acorn

David, your last quote (in italics) in the OP would be harassment I believe? Harassment is against the law.

This are is a murky area, if you break a policy you can be kicked of the website which is 100% legal. Your not allowed to infringe on rights though, you can make someone leave if they don’t allow you to infringe on their rights if your policy states so but of course if it went to the courts you could get in trouble I believe? You could get them in trouble as they didn’t follow your policy (?) but they could get you in trouble for infringing on their rights (?). This could be all wrong though, its just the way I’ve always thought about it.

Read full topic
item.source: Your Rights Online - Freedom of Speech?

item.title: Your Rights Online - Freedom of Speech?
item.dc:creator: @Acorn1 Acorn_
item.description:
@Acorn1 wrote:

The way I see it, the internet is it’s own world.
Websites are it’s country’s, they govern them as they see fit.

Now, here’s an issue I’ve come up with in the past on this website that’s similar.
I was muted by death or somebody twice for not having respect for the deceased, yet my post was in all seriousness and pertained to the topic of the thread. I was muted because someone didn’t agree with my opinion.
That, does not sit right with me. Almost contradicting to what I said above… but w/e

Read full topic
item.source: Your Rights Online - Freedom of Speech?

item.title: Your Rights Online - Freedom of Speech?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

I’m more concerned with the censorship on big site like Youtube and Facebook because of the strong market share.
While I fully support MITB rights to keep this forum clean from bad pics and profanity, I would not say he should have a right to censor certain opinions (As long as they are posted in the right section).

I think he need to recheck his understanding of British law, last I checked, UK will not extradict someone for something that is not a crime in UK.

Read full topic

item.title: Your Rights Online - Freedom of Speech?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“RiiPiiNFtW, post:10, topic:470888”]Trespassing is an entire set of laws. If the person was right across the road from the entrance, they could solicit?[/quote]That’s right. Want to know why? Because that’s not longer private property. Your rights to free speech DO NOT APPLY on private property. You are completely missing the point. The store has nothing against you being on their property. They WANT you on their property to buy their goods. But if you violate their policies (ANY policy, including those about what you can/cant say), they can say you are no longer welcome on their property. The same policy applies online. If you make your own message board (or join one that doesn’t care about what you do), you can say whatever you want on it. But Moparisthebest owns this message board, and he made rules for people to follow if they want to stay on this message board.

Read full topic
item.source: Your Rights Online - Freedom of Speech?

item.title: Your Rights Online - Freedom of Speech?
item.dc:creator: @drubrkletern drubrkletern
item.description:
@drubrkletern wrote:

Any action taken against my signature would be unconstitutional. Moparscape.org is hosted within the US. Which means the US Law and Constitution apply to this website.

The US Constitution does not apply to the Internet, it applies to the Internet within the US. You’re a US Citizen, I am a US Citizen, the forum Owner is a US Citizen. All US Laws apply to us and this forum.

If someone in Britain broke a law that exists here, but not in Britain. The US could have that British citizen shipped oversea to stand trial for his actions. I know you’re smart to realize that the information I am providing you with is valid and stands. So infract me. Would just make you look bad, not me for excersising my rights.

Infracting me for my beliefs is illegal. [snip information that may lead to identification of user]

With that said, it would be AGAINST THE LAW to make an infraction like that.

Damn…
Last I checked the us government doesn’t own moparscape for one, 2, it isn’t illegal because we have our own set of rules, what is against the rules is “illegal” in a way here, it honestly doesn’t have much to do with us laws, even if it was, i doubt the government would put someone on trial for doing their staff job and following the rules of the website by punishing the said victim for flaming, or ship them over here, i doubt they’d care to be honest
